articles.content: When I started working on launching web app , I wanted to try something new: deploy two microservices with a connected strategy. One repo for backend (API + IaC). One repo for frontend (Next.js app). A CodePipeline for backend that provisions Amplify and references the frontend repo. On commit, Amplify picks up changes and hosts the site. This was my first real microservice deployment , connecting two services in one flow. I was excited, but also a bit lost. ‚ö° The Confusion Phase At first, I tho

articles.title: As many as 2 million Cisco devices affected by actively exploited 0-day
articles.description: Search shows 2 million vulnerable Cisco SNMP interfaces exposed to the Internet.
articles.content: As many as 2 million Cisco devices are susceptible to an actively exploited zeroday that can remotely crash or execute code on vulnerable systems. Cisco said Wednesday that the vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20352, was present in all supported versions of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE, the operating system that powers a wide variety of the company‚Äôs networking devices. The vulnerability can be exploited by low-privileged users to create a denial-of-service attack or by higher-privileged users t

That means one decisive hero (location, season, or signature room), one primary act
articles.content: Orientation: what a hotel website must do in 3 moves Hospitality websites win on clarity. Prospective guests arrive with time, place, and price in mind‚Äîyour interface should make those three things instantly legible. That means one decisive hero (location, season, or signature room), one primary action (check availability), and a resilient booking path that survives mid-range phones and shaky Wi-Fi. In my deployments, teams that commit to a minimal, testable stack ship faster and convert better
articles.author: Avry Mcgarvey

It had to go, he thought, if it had any chance of surviving. Wehr, who‚Äôs 26, isn‚Äôt from Greenland‚Äîhe grew up in Germany‚Äîbut he had become obsessed with the
articles.content: When Kenneth Wehr started managing the Greenlandic-language version of Wikipedia four years ago, his first act was to delete almost everything. It had to go, he thought, if it had any chance of surviving. Wehr, who‚Äôs 26, isn‚Äôt from Greenland‚Äîhe grew up in Germany‚Äîbut he had become obsessed with the island, an autonomous Danish territory, after visiting as a teenager. He‚Äôd spent years writing obscure Wikipedia articles in his native tongue on virtually everything to do with it. He even ended up m

articles.title: Nothing is spinning off its budget CMF brand
articles.description: Nothing is spinning off its budget brand CMF into an independent subsidiary, according to a report by TechCrunch . India will serve as the newly-formed company's headquarters for manufacturing and R&D, thanks to a partnership with one of the country's telecom operators. Nothing says this ven
articles.content: Nothing is spinning off its budget brand CMF into an independent subsidiary, according to a report by TechCrunch . India will serve as the newly-formed company's headquarters for manufacturing and R&D, thanks to a partnership with one of the country's telecom operators. Nothing says this venture will create over 1,800 jobs in the country. India is actually a good choice for the HQ. The country is Nothing's strongest market overall, with over a 2 percent market share in smartphones .
articles.author: Lawrence Bonk

articles.description: Networking concepts like IP addresses, subnetting, and CIDR often feel abstract‚Äîjust strings of numbers and slashes. At first glance, 192.168.1.10/24 or 2001:0db8::1 looks like a secret code. But what if we imagine the internet as a city, with streets, neighborhoods, and houses? Suddenly, IPs make s
articles.content: Networking concepts like IP addresses, subnetting, and CIDR often feel abstract‚Äîjust strings of numbers and slashes. At first glance, 192.168.1.10/24 or 2001:0db8::1 looks like a secret code. But what if we imagine the internet as a city, with streets, neighborhoods, and houses? Suddenly, IPs make sense, and data becomes letters traveling along streets. Let‚Äôs take a journey through this digital city. üèôÔ∏è IPv4: The Vintage City IPv4 is like an old, charming city with about 4 billion houses. In th

articles.title: GitHub Copilot gets smarter at finding your code: Inside our new embedding model
articles.description: Learn about a new Copilot embedding model that makes code search in VS Code faster, lighter on memory, and far more accurate. The post GitHub Copilot gets smarter at finding your code: Inside our new embedding model appeared first on The GitHub Blog .
articles.content: Finding the right code quickly is critical. After listening to the community’s feedback, we rolled out a new Copilot embedding model that makes code search in VS Code faster, lighter on memory, and far more accurate. This means retrieving the snippets you actually need instead of near misses. It delivers a 37.6% lift in retrieval quality , about 2x higher throughput , and an 8x smaller index size , so GitHub Copilot chat and agentic responses are more accurate, results return faster, and m
articles.author: Shengyu Fu

articles.content: This week, Commonwealth Fusion Systems announced it has another customer for its first commercial fusion power plant, in Virginia. Eni, one of the world‚Äôs largest oil and gas companies, signed a billion-dollar deal to buy electricity from the facility. One small detail? That reactor doesn‚Äôt exist yet. articles.content: Amazon has agreed to pay $2.5 billion to settle a lawsuit from the Federal Trade Commission, which claimed it tricked millions of customers into subscribing to Prime and made it hard to cancel. Under the agreement, Amazon will pay a $1 billion civil penalty, along with $1.5 billion that it will pay back to an estimated 35 million customers impacted by the company‚Äôs ‚Äúdeceptive‚Äù sign-up process. Amazon must also stop its ‚Äúunlawful enrollment and cancellation practices‚Äù for Prime. A jury was origin
articles.author: Emma Roth

articles.title: Amazon is paying $2.5 billion to settle FTC claims it duped customers into signing up for Prime
articles.description: Amazon will pay a record civil penalty to settle a case with the Federal Trade Commission. The agency accused Amazon of tricking consumers into signing up for a Prime membership without their consent (and making it hard for customers to cancel) in a lawsuit filed in 2023. To settle the charges, Amaz
articles.content: Amazon will pay a record civil penalty to settle a case with the Federal Trade Commission. The agency accused Amazon of tricking consumers into signing up for a Prime membership without their consent (and making it hard for customers to cancel) in a lawsuit filed in 2023. To settle the charges, Amazon has agreed to pay a $1 billion civil penalty and $1.5 billion to refund customers. The company also agreed to "ease unlawful enrollment and cancellation practices for Prime," per the FTC . The agen
articles.author: Kris Holt

articles.content: Elon Musk's xAI is suing OpenAI, alleging that the ChatGPT maker has stolen its trade secrets. articles.content: Spotify has announced a set of policy changes surrounding AI-generated music and spam on its streaming platform. The company is helping to develop an industry standard for AI disclosure in music credits, alongside DDEX . It will be strengthening its approach to AI-assisted spam, such as unauthorized vocal clones, as well as uploaded music that fraudulently delivers music to another artist's profile. The new disclosures will encourage artists to share what aspect, if any, of their production

articles.title: Using AI to map hope for refugees with UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency
articles.description: With the help of GitHub, UNHCR turned drone imagery into maps ‚Äî helping refugees in Kakuma and Kalobeyei build sustainable, powered communities. The post Using AI to map hope for refugees with UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency appeared first on The GitHub Blog .
articles.content: Refugee camps are complex, dynamic ecosystems that often are stood up quickly and develop organically to meet pressing needs. As these settled areas grow, humanitarian aid organizations such as UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, struggle to deliver even the most basic infrastructure and services. In the case of protracted crises when camps become long-term shelters — like the Kalobeyei settlement in Kenya, which shelters more than 300,000 refugees from over 20 countries — the challenge of

articles.title: Apple demands EU repeal the Digital Markets Act
articles.description: "DMA compliance is not optional, it's an obligation," the EU reminds Apple.
articles.content: Apple has demanded Brussels scrap its landmark Big Tech legislation, marking a step up in US tech giants‚Äô fight against European oversight. The EU‚Äôs Digital Markets Act (DMA), which entered into force in 2022, aims to curb the power of Big Tech and level the playing field for smaller rivals, with fines of up to 10 percent of global revenue for companies that do not comply. Apple‚Äôs call to repeal the law comes at a time of transatlantic tensions over the EU‚Äôs digital rule book, including the DMA.
articles.author: Barbara Moens, Financial Times
